sections.heading: Section 1 – Purpose
sections.text: (1) The purpose of this policy is to: provide a framework for the management of student conduct that may cause harm to the RMIT community, ora. might otherwise constitute general misconduct, academic misconduct, high risk misconduct or a breach of an RMIT regulation, policy or procedure support a consistent approach to the management of student conduct mattersb. set out the principles that underpin RMIT’s approach to the reasonable and proportionate regulation of studentc. conduct in order to enable RMIT to discharge its obligations regarding: teaching and research activitiesi. supporting the wellbeing of students and staffii. compliance with government legislationiii. maintenance and protection of academic integrity, andiv. its reasonable requirements regarding programs and courses and their delivery. v.

sections.heading: Section 2 – Overview
sections.text: (2) This policy: establishes the scope and key principles informing RMIT’s student conduct framework and its administrativea. and disciplinary processes for students sets out the primary roles and bodies within RMIT that are responsible for implementing, and have powersb. under, RMIT’s student conduct framework, and provides a structure for handling potential student misconduct and determinations in accordance with thec. Student Conduct Regulations .

sections.heading: Section 3 – Scope
sections.text: (3) This policy applies to all students within the RMIT Group, including: students on approved leave of absence and students who have allowed their enrolment to lapsea. students studying through Open Universities Australia (OUA) or other third-party providers of RMIT courses andb. programs students studying RMIT programs at global partner institutionsc. higher degree by research students, including those who have submitted work for examinationd. graduands or past students, ande. students in single courses.f. This document may be varied, withdrawn or replaced at any time. Printed copies, or part thereof, are regarded as unauthorised and should not be relied upon as the current version. It is the responsibility of the reader to refer to RMIT's Policy Register for the latest version of this document.Page 2 of 9(4) This policy applies to students who are also staff of RMIT. Where a person who is the subject of a potential misconduct report is a student as well as an RMIT staffa. member, staff conduct action may also apply under the relevant framework. The factors determining the policy or policies that will apply are set out in the Student Conduct Procedure . b.

subsections.heading: Principles
subsections.text: (5) Reports of potential student misconduct will be dealt with fairly and in accordance with this policy and corresponding procedures. (6) RMIT is committed to: supporting the welfare and wellbeing of all students, including those about whom a potential studenta. misconduct report is made demonstrating compassion and empathy to students and minimising trauma which can be associated withb. reporting, investigating, hearing, or determining matters which involve harm, including sexual harm, or physical or psychological injury supporting the wellbeing of persons who are affected by or involved in the reported conduct and makingc. reasonable adjustments where a person requires specific support as a result of their age, disability, sex, gender or gender identity, cultural, religious or language background ensuring that the anonymity, confidentiality and privacy of reporting students as well as respondent andd. appellant students is maintained to the extent practicable transparency where there are specific circumstances in which RMIT has an obligation to tell other peoplee. internally about a report, or to make an external report, which may include providing information which identifies a person prompt disclosure of any actual or potential conflict of interest by all parties f. reporting and responding to external authorities where appropriate or required by lawg. acting on and learning from findings of misconduct, identifying problems, improving services, and addressingh. underlying causes and trends to prevent reoccurrence, and being guided by a trauma-informed approach for matters involving sexual, psychological or physical harm. i. (7) Student conduct matters will: be assessed and managed in a professional and fair manner, with clear communications and processes, ina. accordance with the principles of procedural fairness, and be determined utilising “the balance of probabilities” as the requisite standard of proof to be applied whenb. determining matters under this policy and corresponding procedures. (8) RMIT recognises its obligation to support academic freedom and freedom of speech, and to provide the conditions for free enquiry, informed intellectual discourse and reasoned debate in accordance with the Intellectual Freedom Policy . The exercise of academic freedom and freedom of speech by a student, subject to the limitations detailed in thea. Intellectual Freedom Policy , will not constitute misconduct nor attract any penalty or other adverse action by reference only to its content. This document may be varied, withdrawn or replaced at any time. Printed copies, or part thereof, are regarded as unauthorised and should not be relied upon as the current version. It is the responsibility of the reader to refer to RMIT's Policy Register for the latest version of this document.Page 3 of 9Student Conduct (9) Students must behave in a manner that is consistent with RMIT’s commitment to providing a safe learning and working environment. RMIT fosters an environment of mutual respect. As members of a diverse community, students must treat others with respect, and are entitled to be respected. (10) RMIT will take appropriate action to address conduct that may cause harm to members of the RMIT community or might otherwise constitute misconduct or a breach of an RMIT regulation, policy or procedure. (11) The Student Conduct Regulations prescribe the categories of general, academic and high risk misconduct; a non- exhaustive list of behaviours comprising general and academic misconduct are set out within Student Conduct Policy Schedule 1 - Student Misconduct to this policy. (12) Where a potential student misconduct report appears to involve a potential breach of research integrity, the matter will be reported to the Research Integrity Office where action may be taken in accordance with the Research Policy and Research Integrity Breach Management Procedure , however any such action will not result in a student conduct outcome.

subsections.heading: Executive Suspension
subsections.text: (13) The purpose of an executive suspension is to manage immediate risk caused by high risk student misconduct. (14) If the University Secretary and Academic Registrar receives a report regarding potential high risk student misconduct, the University Secretary and Academic Registrar may make a recommendation to the Vice-Chancellor or delegate that an executive suspension be imposed on a student in accordance with Regulation 23 of the Student Conduct Regulations to manage immediate risk. (15) The University Secretary and Academic Registrar's recommendation will provide details about the potential high risk student misconduct. The recommendation may also propose additional terms, conditions or directions regarding an executive suspension, such as: measures to ensure that all parties are safe and that the student is offered the support necessary to return toa. study directions to a student not to attend campus or other RMIT premisesb. directions to a student relating to contact or communication with other students, staff, or other members of thec. RMIT community conditions or restrictions on the times or dates, or the way in which, a student may attend RMIT premises ord. participate in RMIT-related events, activities, and functions, including where those events or activities occur online restrictions on a student’s access to or use of RMIT facilities or resources, including computing and networke. facilities, such as online learning portals, email or other RMIT technology infrastructure or services, or restrictions applying to or a suspension of a student’s enrolment.f. (16) If a student does not comply with any of the terms, conditions or directions of an executive suspension, this non- compliance may itself be misconduct under the Student Conduct Policy . (17) Where there is a report of potential student misconduct associated with an executive suspension, the matter will be heard by the Student Conduct Board to determine if there has been student misconduct, and whether any other consequences or penalties should apply. For the avoidance of doubt, an executive suspension may be imposed independent of a student conduct process for the purposes of managing immediate risk. This document may be varied, withdrawn or replaced at any time. Printed copies, or part thereof, are regarded as unauthorised and should not be relied upon as the current version. It is the responsibility of the reader to refer to RMIT's Policy Register for the latest version of this document.Page 4 of 9Temporary Suspension (18) A student whose behaviour is disrupting RMIT activities, damaging property, or endangering others, may immediately in response to that incident be required to leave the premises and not return that day by any staff member responsible for: a teaching or assessment sessiona. a class or meeting conducted by, or for, RMITb. an RMIT facility or areac. any other activity within the precincts of RMIT.d. (19) The staff member will report both the incident and the action taken to the relevant Senior Officer as soon as practicable.

subsections.heading: Hearing and Determining Reports of Potential Student Misconduct
Senior Officers and Student Conduct Board
subsections.text: (20) Senior Officers and the Student Conduct Board, in accordance with Part G of the Student Conduct Regulations , this policy and corresponding procedures, may: consider potential misconduct reportsa. make and direct investigationsb. conduct hearings, andc. make determinations regarding findings of fact, whether misconduct has occurred and any appropriate actions,d. consequences or penalties to be applied.

subsections.heading: Student Conduct Appeals Committee
subsections.text: (21) The Student Conduct Appeals Committee, in accordance with the Student Conduct Regulations , this policy and corresponding procedures, may consider and make determinations in response to eligible student appeal submissions that have been lodged against decisions (findings of fact), or the consequences or penalties applied by: a Senior Officer, ora. the Student Conduct Board. b.

subsections.heading: Consequences and/or Penalties of Misconduct Findings
Senior Officers
subsections.text: (22) A Senior Officer may apply consequences or penalties in finding that a respondent student has engaged in misconduct in accordance with the Student Conduct Regulation 43. Where a Senior Officer requires a student to undertake or participate in any educative, learning, mediation ora. resolution focused activity in accordance with Regulation 43(h), this may be achieved through any of the following: facilitated discussions, coaching or an educative activity, between the student and other relevant ori. affected staff or students, or any other learning or resolution-focussed activity supporting the student to understand the impact or effect of their actions, including through participationii. in counselling requiring the student to provide an undertaking not to engage in the misconduct again iii. mediation of associated matters iv. subsections.heading: Student Conduct Board
subsections.text: (23) The Student Conduct Board may apply consequences and/or penalties in finding that a respondent student has engaged in misconduct in accordance with the Student Conduct Regulation 45.

subsections.heading: Senior Officers and Student Conduct Board
subsections.text: (24) In determining what actions to take or consequences or penalties to implement, a Senior Officer or Student Conduct Board will, where appropriate and to the extent practicable, take into account what actions or consequences the persons who have been impacted or affected by the student’s misconduct would prefer to be implemented. For example, a conciliatory or mediated outcome may be appropriate where the misconduct is not of a serious nature but has still had an impact or effect on another person, and where the impacted or affected person wishes to undertake conciliation or mediation. (25) A determination relating to grades or marks in an assessment task or course (including recording a failure) overrides grades or marks already assigned and determinations made in relation to the assessment task or course grade or mark under any other policy.

subsections.heading: Appeals, External Reviews and Other Proceedings
subsections.text: (26) Subject to satisfying eligibility requirements, students may request a hearing of the Student Conduct Appeals Committee to consider an appeal against a misconduct decision made by a Senior Officer or the Student Conduct Board. (27) Students may exercise their right to external review of determinations made under this policy, associated procedures, and the Student Conduct Regulations . (28) RMIT may suspend or pause any internal process under this policy where the student exercises their right to external review of a determination involving the same or similar subject matter, or where the same or similar subject matter is subject to legal proceedings, or any other external, regulatory or investigative processes or proceedings, including criminal investigations, or professional disciplinary proceedings. If such a suspension or pause is applied to allow a student to exercise an external right of review, and delay,a. loss, or any other detriment flows from that suspension or pause, then that delay, loss, or detriment is, to the extent that it affects the student, the responsibility of the student.

subsections.heading: Responsibilities
subsections.text: (29) Students must comply with the: RMIT Student Charter a. RMIT regulations, policies and procedures relating to student behaviour and conduct, including thoseb. concerning acceptable use of network, internet and email facilities and services, and RMIT Statement of Student Responsibilities . c. (30) Officers must report conduct in accordance with this policy upon receiving information and forming a reasonable belief that a student may have engaged in misconduct as defined in this policy. (31) Senior Officers are responsible for: This document may be varied, withdrawn or replaced at any time. Printed copies, or part thereof, are regarded as unauthorised and should not be relied upon as the current version. It is the responsibility of the reader to refer to RMIT's Policy Register for the latest version of this document.Page 6 of 9assessing and referring conduct mattersa. undertaking and directing investigations, determining reports of potential general and academic studentb. misconduct as prescribed by this policy, and managing student conduct records, analysis, and reporting.c. (32) The University Secretary and Academic Registrar (or delegate) is responsible for: oversight, compliance and the review of this policy, and approval of corresponding procedures and guidancea. materials identifying opportunities for continuous improvementb. maintaining and publishing the register of Senior Officersc. determining eligibility of student appeal submissionsd. liaising with external parties such as police and other government bodiese. monitoring high risk misconductf. managing the Student Conduct Board and Student Conduct Appeals Committee hearing process includingg. proceedings authorising notifications to external authorities, including mandatory reporting, andh. misconduct trend reporting and analysis, including annual reports to Academic Board.i. (33) Senior Officers are appointed in accordance with the Student Conduct Regulations . (34) Senior Officers are predominantly drawn from positions reporting to Executives or Senior Executives of RMIT, upon the advice of the University Secretary and Academic Registrar. The University Secretary and Academic Registrar is notified of appointments.

subsections.heading: Compliance
subsections.text: (35) Where a student has not complied with or fulfilled any direction, penalty or consequence imposed or applied under this policy or its corresponding procedures by the prescribed date, subject to the absolute discretion of the University Secretary and Academic Registrar, RMIT will not: permit the student to re-enrola. issue or provide the student with any statement of results, orb. grant the student any award.c. (36) Where a member of staff fails to comply with the provisions of this policy or corresponding procedures, the matter may be referred for disciplinary action. (37) Breaches of this policy by a student (including any malicious or vexatious reports) may be treated as general misconduct in accordance with this policy.

subsections.heading: Review
subsections.text: (38) This policy will be reviewed at least once every five (5) years in accordance with the Policy Governance Policy .

sections.text: (Note: Commonly defined terms are in the RMIT Policy Glossary. Any defined terms below are specific to this policy). Academic freedommeans the freedom of students to engage in intellectual enquiry, express their opinions in relation to RMIT, and to participate in student societies and associations, as detailed in the Student Conduct Regulations . Appellant studentis a student who seeking to appeal against a ﬁnding of misconduct, or the consequences or penalty applied by a Senior Oﬃcer or Student Conduct Board. Assessment session means the speciﬁed period in which the assessment task is conducted. Assessment taskmeans any examination, essay, assignment, practical or vocational placement or other work, in whole or in part, which forms part of a student’s academic assessment. Balance of probabilitiesmeans the standard of proof that requires a decision maker to consider whether it is “more probable than not” that an action, incident, or event had occurred as reported. Computing and network facilitiesincludes, but is not limited to, computers, computer systems, email and other communications networks and information facilities together with associated software, ﬁles and data storage and retrieval. Cost of any damagemeans the monetary value of any damage to, or loss of, any property (including the cost of repair or replacement). Course materialsmeans materials produced by staﬀ to support or facilitate teaching, learning, development and assessment such as: lecture or tutorial notes, presentations, recordings, assessment tasks and documentation (essay, assignment, test or exam questions, grading rubrics or assessment criteria), study guides and resources. Document fraudmeans knowingly falsifying, forging or submitting documents that contain misleading or false information. Misconductincludes general misconduct, academic misconduct and/or high risk misconduct as deﬁned in the Student Conduct Regulations and referenced in this policy. Oﬃcer means any person employed or engaged as staﬀ within the RMIT Group. Plagiarisemeans the presentation of the work, idea, or creation of another person, without appropriate referencing, as though it is one's own. PlagiarismThe presentation of the work, idea or creation of another person as though it is one’s own. Plagiarism is a form of cheating and is a serious academic oﬀence that may lead to expulsion from the University. Plagiarised material can be drawn from, and presented in, written, graphic or visual form, including electronic data, and oral presentations. Plagiarism occurs when the origin of the material used is not appropriately cited. Respondent studentis a student who is reported to have engaged in conduct which might, if proven, constitute misconduct, or who has been found to have engaged in misconduct. qa_index.title: Section 7 – Definitions
qa_index.text: (Note: Commonly defined terms are in the RMIT Policy Glossary. Any defined terms below are specific to this policy). Academic freedommeans the freedom of students to engage in intellectual enquiry, express their opinions in relation to RMIT, and to participate in student societies and associations, as detailed in the Student Conduct Regulations . Appellant studentis a student who seeking to appeal against a ﬁnding of misconduct, or the consequences or penalty applied by a Senior Oﬃcer or Student Conduct Board. Assessment session means the speciﬁed period in which the assessment task is conducted. Assessment taskmeans any examination, essay, assignment, practical or vocational placement or other work, in whole or in part, which forms part of a student’s academic assessment. Balance of probabilitiesmeans the standard of proof that requires a decision maker to consider whether it is “more probable than not” that an action, incident, or event had occurred as reported. Computing and network facilitiesincludes, but is not limited to, computers, computer systems, email and other communications networks and information facilities together with associated software, ﬁles and data storage and retrieval. Cost of any damagemeans the monetary value of any damage to, or loss of, any property (including the cost of repair or replacement). Course materialsmeans materials produced by staﬀ to support or facilitate teaching, learning, development and assessment such as: lecture or tutorial notes, presentations, recordings, assessment tasks and documentation (essay, assignment, test or exam questions, grading rubrics or assessment criteria), study guides and resources. Document fraudmeans knowingly falsifying, forging or submitting documents that contain misleading or false information. Misconductincludes general misconduct, academic misconduct and/or high risk misconduct as deﬁned in the Student Conduct Regulations and referenced in this policy. Oﬃcer means any person employed or engaged as staﬀ within the RMIT Group. Plagiarisemeans the presentation of the work, idea, or creation of another person, without appropriate referencing, as though it is one's own. PlagiarismThe presentation of the work, idea or creation of another person as though it is one’s own. Plagiarism is a form of cheating and is a serious academic oﬀence that may lead to expulsion from the University. Plagiarised material can be drawn from, and presented in, written, graphic or visual form, including electronic data, and oral presentations. Plagiarism occurs when the origin of the material used is not appropriately cited. Respondent studentis a student who is reported to have engaged in conduct which might, if proven, constitute misconduct, or who has been found to have engaged in misconduct. (5) Reports of potential student misconduct will be dealt with fairly and in accordance with this policy and corresponding procedures. (10) RMIT will take appropriate action to address conduct that may cause harm to members of the RMIT community or might otherwise constitute misconduct or a breach of an RMIT regulation, policy or procedure. Section 4 – Policy :: Executive Suspension
(13) The purpose of an executive suspension is to manage immediate risk caused by high risk student misconduct. (14) If the University Secretary and Academic Registrar receives a report regarding potential high risk student misconduct, the University Secretary and Academic Registrar may make a recommendation to the Vice-Chancellor or delegate that an executive suspension be imposed on a student in accordance with Regulation 23 of the Student Conduct Regulations to manage immediate risk. (15) The University Secretary and Academic Registrar's recommendation will provide details about the potential high risk student misconduct. The recommendation may also propose additional terms, conditions or directions regarding an executive suspension, such as: measures to ensure that all parties are safe and that the student is offered the support necessary to return toa. study directions to a student not to attend campus or other RMIT premisesb. directions to a student relating to contact or communication with other students, staff, or other members of thec. RMIT community conditions or restrictions on the times or dates, or the way in which, a student may attend RMIT premises ord. participate in RMIT-related events, activities, and functions, including where those events or activities occur online restrictions on a student’s access to or use of RMIT facilities or resources, including computing and networke. facilities, such as online learning portals, email or other RMIT technology infrastructure or services, or restrictions applying to or a suspension of a student’s enrolment.f. (16) If a student does not comply with any of the terms, conditions or directions of an executive suspension, this non- compliance may itself be misconduct under the Student Conduct Policy . (17) Where there is a report of potential student misconduct associated with an executive suspension, the matter will be heard by the Student Conduct Board to determine if there has been student misconduct, and whether any other consequences or penalties should apply. For the avoidance of doubt, an executive suspension may be imposed independent of a student conduct process for the purposes of managing immediate risk.
